column4: Why does my desktop go into initramfs with the message ALERT! /dev/disk/by-uuid... does not exist.. WHen I push control-alt-tab on bootup, it works tho.
I've checked the uuid number with blkid, and its there.
what does ctrl-alt-tab do? and when are you pressing it?
I just got told here earlier to press it.. not sure what it does really.. I'm pressing it right after the bios.
after the bios but before grub?
i guess im wondering why ctrl-alt-tab and not ctrl-alt-6 or shift-tab or any other random combination of keys
the ubuntu screen is there.. with the timebar.
so at plymouth
maybe it's tab+control. or tab+alt.. I don't remember.
I just pushed them all.. and I got back in, phew!.
but I want to get rid of that when it boots.

i cant imagine what that key would be doing. there really isnt anything in the early boot that listens for keypresses. im guessing the act of pressing the key is causing just enough delay to avoid some kind of race condition in device enumeration... but it sounds odd. I would try one of the kernel rootwait argumenet
so in /etc/default/grub on the CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT add "rootdelay=5"
correct?: GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT="quiet splash rootdelay=5"
sure. then sudo update-grub
thanks, then i'll reboot and try it. :-)
thanks. it worked :-)
given how tight your race condition is you could probably drop to rootdelay=1 if those 4 seconds are important to you
pretty quick now. :-)
its just really strange.. you must have a race that is only a few microseconds... otherwise a keyboard interrupt isn't going to do anything useful
so you think I should just try for the curiosity of it.. to make it 1 second?

if you are really curious you can start building your own kernels and bisect back to the change that caused this. depends on how much you care and how much your time is worth.... when you spend days trying to figure out what happens in a millisecond... that makes you a kernel developer i guess
it's probably fixed in a newer version of ubuntu.
